## Evan Drumwright

![Evan Drumwright](http://edrumwri.github.io/assets/img/evan-color2.jpg)

### Bio

I graduated in 2007 from The University of Southern California with a Ph. D.
in Computer Science (concentrating on robotics) under [Maja Mataric'](http://www-robotics.usc.edu/~maja/). I graduated from the University of Memphis (which has one of the top mathematics programs in the US) with a B.S. in Mathematics and a B.S. in Computer Science (1999).

I discovered the [first polynomial time model for simultaneous impacts between rigid bodies](http://robotics.gwu.edu/positronics/wp-content/uploads/2013/08/WAFR10.pdf), the [first quadratic algorithm for inverting generalized inertia matrices](http://positronicslab.github.io/assets/pdfs/simpar.pdf), and the [first algorithm for computing inverse dynamics under the rigid contact model](http://positronicslab.github.io/assets/pdfs/inverse-dynamics.pdf) (with my student [Sam Zapolsky](http://samzapo.github.io)).

My work has been funded by NSF, Willow Garage, Open Source Robotics Foundation/NASA, and Hewlett Packard.



### Lab

I run the [Positronics Lab](http://positronicslab.github.io) (Planning Optimization and Simulation for Robotics) at [GWU](www.gwu.edu). Please see my lab web page for publications, students, facilities, and joining my research group.

### Research

My research focus lies primarily in _simulating the dynamics_ of manipulator, humanoid, and legged robots and _applications of such simulations_. Simulation can speed the edit-compile-test cycle for manual programming, can be used to develop models used for robot learning, and can be an integral part of a robot's planning process.

More broadly, I am interested in algorithms for robot kinematics and dynamics, numerical algorithms (including algorithms for constrained nonlinear optimization), and computational geometry and geometric intersection algorithms.
